instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.D7105: What is D7105? Diodes between PPDCIN_G3H charger voltage and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, when CHGR_DCIN Is low(less than charger voltage) and PPBUS_G3H is missing this is a critical point to troubleshoot.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V
threads.message:
This board has no fan, no green light on charger.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.45V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V
On <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, pin 2 : <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>=0V. I checked <DIODE>D7105</DIODE>, in diode mode I have 2.85V in one way and 2.27V in the other, so I believe it is dead (values on a good one: 3V and 0.25V)
On <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, resistance on pin 2 is 2 ohm (expected 80 ohm) so I believe this ISL is also dead.

Is there anything else I should check before replacing these 2, to avoid them frying again immediately? I don't see shorts on <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, resistance between pins 27/28 is 20.8Î©

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V
threads.message:
Remove <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and check diode mode to ground at pins 2, 19, 20.
If all good, solder new ISL6259A; may need to replace R/<DIODE>D7105</DIODE> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <DIODE>D7105</DIODE> removed.

pin 2: 0V   R=22.2 ohm
pin 19: 0.33V   R= 65kohm
pin 20: 0.33V   R= 65kohm

I removed <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>, pin 2: 3.1 V
But then on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>/pin 3 of <DIODE>D7105</DIODE> (<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN_D_R</SIGNAL>), I had again 0V, 2.2 ohm. The boardview shows a link to <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR>, and finally it was <CAPACITOR>C7190</CAPACITOR> shorted!

I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7190</CAPACITOR>, <DIODE>D7105</DIODE>. I soldered back the same ISL, now I see orange light on charger, but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=1.1V

Here are <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages:
1 = 16.5V
2 = 17.8V
3 = 4.3V
9 = 0V 
12 = 3.4V 
13 = 3.4V 
14 = 3.4V
15 = 0V
17 = 1.1V
19 = 5.5V
20 = 5.5V
27 = 1.1V

Is ISL dead, or is there any other components to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V
threads.message:
Remove F7140 and check <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> voltage.
If bad, change <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>.
If still the same, try another ISL6259A.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V
threads.message:
I removed F7140, same voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR>
I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> from a donor board, same voltage
I replaced ISL6259A also from a donor board, and now I finally have 12.6V. Thanks for the help
I have a question about <CHIP>ISL9259</CHIP>: can <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> AHRTZ be replaced with <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> HRTZ, for example from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards? I cannot find datasheets for them

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V
threads.message: It probably works; question of test...
